verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:1
verses.text: Moses of Chorene: History of Armenia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:2
verses.text: I.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:3
verses.text: Reign of Abgar; Armenia becomes completely tributary to the Romans; war with Herod's troops; his brother's son, Joseph, is killed.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:4
verses.text: Abgar, son of Archam, ascends the throne in the twentieth year of Archavir, king of the Persians.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:5
verses.text: This Abgar was called Avak-air (great man), on account of his great gentleness and wisdom, and also on account of his size.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:6
verses.text: Not being able to pronounce well, the Greeks and the Syrians called him Abgar.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:7
verses.text: In the second year of his reign, all the districts of Armenia become tributary to the Romans.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:8
verses.text: A command is given by the Emperor Augustus, as we are told in the Gospel of St.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:9
verses.text: Luke, to number all the people in every part.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:10
verses.text: Roman commissioners, sent for that purpose into Armenia, carried thither the statue of the Emperor Augustus, and set it up in all the temples.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:11
verses.text: At this very time, our Saviour Jesus Christ, the Son of God, came into the world.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:12
verses.text: At the same period there was trouble between Abgar and Herod:  for Herod wished that his statue should be erected near to that of Caesar in the temples of Armenia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:13
verses.text: Abgar withstood this claim.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:14
verses.text: Moreover, Herod was but seeking a pretext to attack Abgar:  he sent an army of Thracians and Germans to make an incursion into the country of the Persians, with orders to pass through the territories of Abgar.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:15
verses.text: But Abgar, far from submitting to this, resisted, saying that the emperor's command was to march the troops into Persia through the desert.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:16
verses.text: Herod, indignant, and unable to act by himself, overwhelmed with troubles, as a punishment for his wicked conduct towards Christ, as Josephus relates, sent his nephew to whom he had given his daughter, who had been married in the first instance to Phéror, his brother.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:17
verses.text: Herod's lieutenant, at the head of a considerable army, hastened to reach Mesopotamia, met Abgar at the camp in the province of Pouknan, fell in the combat, and his troops were put to flight.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 1:18
verses.text: Soon afterwards, Herod died: Archelaus, his son, was appointed by Augustus ethnarch of Judaea.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:1
verses.text: II.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:2
verses.text: Founding of the town of Edessa; brief account of the race of our illuminator.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:3
verses.text: A little while afterwards, Augustus dies, and Tiberius becomes emperor of the Romans in his stead.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:4
verses.text: Germanicus, having become Caesar, dragging in his train the princes of the kingdom of Archavir and of Abgar, celebrates a triumph in respect of the war waged with them, in which these princes had killed Herod's nephew.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:5
verses.text: Abgar, indignant, forms plans of revolt and prepares himself for combat.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:6
verses.text: He builds a town on the ground occupied by the Armenian army of observation, where previously the Euphrates had been defended against the attempts of Cassius:  this new town is called Edessa.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:7
verses.text: Abgar removed to it his court, which was at Medzpine, all his gods, Naboc, Bel, Patnicagh, and Tarata, the books of the schools attached to the temples, and even the royal archives.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:8
verses.text: After this, Archavir being dead, Ardachès, his son, reigns over the Persians.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:9
verses.text: Though it is not in the order of the history with respect to time, nor even the order according to which we have begun these annals, yet, as we are treating of descendants of the king Archavir, even of the blood of Ardachès his son, we will, to do honour to these princes, place them, by anticipating the time, near to Ardachès, in order that the reader may know that they are of the same race, of the race of the brave Archag; then we will indicate the time of the arrival of their fathers in Armenia, the Garenians and the Sourenians, from whom St.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:10
verses.text: Gregory and the Gamsarians are descended, when, following the order of events, we come to the reign of the king under whom they appeared.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 2:11
verses.text: Abgar did not succeed in his plans of revolt; for, troubles having arisen amongst his relatives in the Persian kingdom, he set out at the head of an army to allay and bring to an end the dissension.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:2
verses.text: Abgar comes into the East, maintains Ardachès upon the throne of Persia; reconciles his brothers from whom our illuminator and his relations are descended.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:3
verses.text: Abgar, having gone to the East, finds on the throne of Persia Ardachès, son of Archavir, and the brothers of Ardachès contending against him:  for this prince thought to reign over them in his posterity, and they would not consent to it.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:4
verses.text: Ardachès therefore hems them in on all sides, hangs the sword of death over their heads; distractions and dissension were between their troops and their other relations and allies:  for King Archavir had three sons and one daughter; the first of these sons was King Ardachès himself, the second Garene, the third Sourene; their sister, named Gochm, was wife of the general of all the Ariks, a general chosen by their father Archavir.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:5
verses.text: Abgar prevails on the sons of Archavir to make peace; he arranges between them the conditions and stipulations:  Ardachès is to reign with his posterity as he proposed, and his brothers are to be called Bahlav, from the name of their town and their vast and fertile country, so that their satrapies shall be the first, higher in rank than all the satrapies of Persia, as being truly a race of kings.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:6
verses.text: Treaties and oaths stipulated that in case of the extinction of male children of Ardachès, his brothers should come to the throne; after the reigning race of Ardachès, his brothers are divided into three races named thus:  the race of Garene Bahlav, the race of Sourene Bahlav, and the race of their sister, the race of Asbahabied Bahlav, a race thus called from the name of the domain of her husband.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:7
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:8
verses.text: Gregory is said to have sprung from the race Sourene Bahlav, and the Gamsarians from the race Garene Bahlav.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:9
verses.text: We will relate in the sequel the circumstances of the coming of these personages, only mentioning their names here in connection with Ardachès, in order that you may know that these great races are indeed the blood of Vagharchag, that is to say, the posterity of the great Archag, brother of Vagharchag.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 3:10
verses.text: Everything being thus arranged, Abgar takes with him the letter of the treaties, and returns to his dominions; not in perfect health, but a prey to severe suffering.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:1
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:2
verses.text: Abgar returns from the east; he gives help to Aretas in a war against Herod the Tetrarch.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:3
verses.text: When Abgar had returned from the East, he learnt that the Romans suspected him of having gone there to raise troops.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:4
verses.text: He therefore made the Roman commissioners acquainted with the reasons of his journey to Persia, as well as the treaty concluded between Ardachès and his brothers; but no credence was given to his statement:  for he was accused by his enemies Pilate, Herod the tetrarch, Lysanias and Philip.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:5
verses.text: Abgar having returned to his city Edessa leagued himself with Aretas, king of Petra, and gave him some auxiliary troops under the command of Khosran Ardzrouni, to make war upon Herod.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:6
verses.text: Herod had in the first instance married the daughter of Aretas, then had repudiated her, and thereupon taken Herodias, even in her husband's lifetime, a circumstance in connection with which he had had John the Baptist put to death.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:7
verses.text: Consequently there was war between Herod and Aretas on account of the wrong done the daughter of Aretas.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 4:8
verses.text: Being sharply attacked, Herod's troops were defeated, thanks to the help of the brave Armenians; as if, by divine providence, vengeance was taken for the death of John the Baptist.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:1
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:2
verses.text: Abgar sends princes to Marinus; these deputies see our Saviour Christ; beginning of the conversion of Abgar.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:3
verses.text: At this period Marinus, son of Storoge, was raised by the emperor to the government of Phoenicia, Palestine, Syria, and Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:4
verses.text: Abgar sent to him two of his principal officers, Mar-Ihap prince of Aghtznik, and Chamchacram chief of the house of the Abahouni, as well as Anan his confidant.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:5
verses.text: The envoys proceed to the town of Petkoupine to make known to Marinus the reasons of Abgar's journey to the East, showing him the treaty concluded between Ardachès and his brothers, and at the same time to call upon Marinus for his support.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:6
verses.text: The deputies found the Roman governor at Eleutheropolis; he received them with friendship and distinction, and gave this answer to Abgar:  "Fear nothing from the emperor on that account, provided you take good care to pay the tribute regularly".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:7
verses.text: On their return, the Armenian deputies went to Jerusalem to see our Saviour the Christ, being attracted by the report of His miracles.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:8
verses.text: Having themselves become eye-witnesses of these wonders, they related them to Abgar.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:9
verses.text: This prince, seized with admiration, believed truly that Jesus was indeed the Son of God, and said:  "These wonders are not those of a man, but of a God.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:10
verses.text: No, there is no one amongst men who can raise the dead:  God alone has this power".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:11
verses.text: Abgar felt in his whole body certain acute pains which he had got in Persia, more than seven years before; from men he had received no remedy for his sufferings; Abgar sent a letter of entreaty to Jesus:  he prayed Him to come and cure him of his pains.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 5:12
verses.text: Here is this letter:—.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:1
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:2
verses.text: Abgar's letter to the Saviour Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:3
verses.text: "Abgar, son of Archam, prince of the land, to Jesus, Saviour and Benefactor of men, who has appeared in the country of Jerusalem, greeting:—  "I have heard of Thee, and of the cures wrought by Thy hands, without remedies, without herbs:  for, as it is said, Thou makest the blind to see, the lame to walk, the lepers to be healed; Thou drivest out unclean spirits, Thou curest unhappy beings afflicted with prolonged and inveterate diseases; Thou dost even raise the dead.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:4
verses.text: As I have heard of all these wonders wrought by Thee, I have concluded from them either that Thou art God, come down from heaven to do such great things, or that Thou art the Son of God, working as Thou dost these miracles.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:5
verses.text: Therefore have I written to Thee, praying Thee to condescend to come to me and cure me of the complaints with which I am afflicted.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:6
verses.text: I have heard also that the Jews murmur against Thee and wish to deliver Thee up to torments:  I have a city small but pleasant, it would be sufficient for us both".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:7
verses.text: The messengers, the bearers of this letter, met Jesus at Jerusalem, a fact confirmed by these words of the Gospel:  "Some from amongst the heathen came to find Jesus, but those who heard them, not daring to tell Jesus what they had heard, told it to Philip and Andrew, who repeated it all to their Master".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 6:8
verses.text: The Saviour did not then accept the invitation given to Him, but He thought fit to honour Abgar with an answer in these words:—.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 7:1
verses.text: VII.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 7:2
verses.text: Answer to Abgar's letter, which the apostle Thomas wrote to this prince by command of the Saviour.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 7:3
verses.text: "Blessed is he who believes in me without having seen me!  For it is written of me:  'Those who see me will not believe in me, and those who do not see me will believe and live.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 7:4
verses.text: '  As to what thou hast written asking me to come to thee, I must accomplish here all that for which I have been sent; and, when I shall have accomplished it all, I shall ascend to Him who sent me; and when I shall go away I will send one of my disciples, who will cure thy diseases, and give life to thee and to all those who are with thee".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 7:5
verses.text: Anan, Abgar's courier, brought him this letter, as well as the portrait of the Saviour, a picture which is still to be found at this day in the city of Edessa.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:1
verses.text: VIII.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:2
verses.text: Preaching of the apostle Thaddaeus at Edessa; copy of five letters.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:3
verses.text: After the ascension of our Saviour, the Apostle Thomas, one of the twelve, sent one of the seventy-six disciples, Thaddaeus, to the city of Edessa to heal Abgar and to preach the Gospel, according to the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:4
verses.text: Thaddaeus came to the house of Tobias, a Jewish prince, who is said to have been of the race of the Pacradouni.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:5
verses.text: Tobias, having left Archam, did not abjure Judaism with the rest of his relatives, but followed its laws up to the moment when he believed in Christ.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:6
verses.text: Soon the name of Thaddaeus spreads through the whole town.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:7
verses.text: Abgar, on learning of his arrival, said:  "This is indeed he concerning whom Jesus wrote to me;" and immediately Abgar sent for the apostle.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:8
verses.text: When Thaddaeus entered, a marvellous appearance presented itself to the eyes of Abgar in the countenance of the apostle; the king having risen from his throne, fell on his face to the earth, and prostrated himself before Thaddaeus.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:9
verses.text: This spectacle greatly surprised all the princes who were present, for they were ignorant of the fact of the vision.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:10
verses.text: "Art thou really," said Abgar to Thaddaeus, "art thou the disciple of the ever-blessed Jesus?  Art thou he whom He promised to send to me, and canst thou heal my maladies?"  "Yes," answered Thaddaeus; "if thou believest in Jesus Christ, the Son of God, the desires of thy heart shall be granted".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:11
verses.text: "I have believed in Jesus," said Abgar, "I have believed in His Father; therefore I wished to go at the head of my troops to destroy the Jews who have crucified Jesus, had I not been prevented by reason of the power of the Romans".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:12
verses.text: Thenceforth Thaddaeus began to preach the Gospel to the king and his town; laying his hands upon Abgar, he cured him; he cured also a man with gout, Abdu, a prince of the town, much honoured in all the king's house.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:13
verses.text: He also healed all the sick and infirm people in the town, and all believed in Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:14
verses.text: Abgar was baptized, and all the town with him, and the temples of the false gods were closed, and all the statues of idols that were placed on the altars and columns were hidden by being covered with reeds.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:15
verses.text: Abgar did not compel any one to embrace the faith yet from day to day the number of the believers was multiplied.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:16
verses.text: The Apostle Thaddaeus baptizes a manufacturer of silk head-dresses, called Attaeus, consecrates him, appoints him to minister at Edessa, and leaves him with the king instead of himself.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:17
verses.text: Thaddaeus, after having received letters patent from Abgar, who wished that all should listen to the Gospel of Christ, went to find Sanadroug, son of Abgar's sister, whom this prince had appointed over the country and over the army.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:18
verses.text: Abgar was pleased to write to the Emperor Tiberius a letter in these words:—  Abgar's letter to Tiberius.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:19
verses.text: "Abgar, king of Armenia, to my Lord Tiberius, emperor of the Romans, greeting:—  "I know that nothing is unknown to your Majesty, but, as your friend, I would make you better acquainted with the facts by writing.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:20
verses.text: The Jews who dwell in the cantons of Palestine have crucified Jesus:  Jesus without sin, Jesus after so many acts of kindness, so many wonders and miracles wrought for their good, even to the raising of the dead.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:21
verses.text: Be assured that these are not the effects of the power of a simple mortal, but of God.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:22
verses.text: During the time that they were crucifying Him, the sun was darkened, the earth was moved, shaken; Jesus Himself, three days afterwards, rose from the dead and appeared to many.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:23
verses.text: Now, everywhere, His name alone, invoked by His disciples, produces the greatest miracles:  what has happened to myself is the most evident proof of it.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:24
verses.text: Your august Majesty knows henceforth what ought to be done in future with respect to the Jewish nation, which has committed this crime; your Majesty knows whether a command should not be published through the whole universe to worship Christ as the true God.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:25
verses.text: Safety and health".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:26
verses.text: Answer from Tiberius to Abgar's letter.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:27
verses.text: "Tiberius, emperor of the Romans, to Abgar, king of the Armenians, greeting:—  "Your kind letter has been read to me, and I wish that thanks should be given to you from me.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:28
verses.text: Though we had already heard several persons relate these facts, Pilate has officially informed us of the miracles of Jesus.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:29
verses.text: He has certified to us that after His resurrection from the dead He was acknowledged by many to be God.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:30
verses.text: Therefore I myself also wished to do what you propose; but, as it is the custom of the Romans not to admit a god merely by the command of the sovereign, but only when the admission has been discussed and examined in full senate, I proposed the affair to the senate, and they rejected it with contempt, doubtless because it had not been considered by them first.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:31
verses.text: But we have commanded all those whom Jesus suits, to receive him amongst the gods.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:32
verses.text: We have threatened with death any one who shall speak evil of the Christians.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:33
verses.text: As to the Jewish nation which has dared to crucify Jesus, who, as I hear, far from deserving the cross and death, was worthy of honour, worthy of the adoration of men—when I am free from the war with rebellious Spain, I will examine into the matter, and will treat the Jews as they deserve".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:34
verses.text: Abgar writes another letter to Tiberius.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:35
verses.text: "Abgar, king of the Armenians, to my lord Tiberius, emperor of the Romans, greeting:—  "I have received the letter written from your august Majesty, and I have applauded the commands which have emanated from your wisdom.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:36
verses.text: If you will not be angry with me, I will say that the conduct of the senate is extremely ridiculous and absurd:  for, according to the senators, it is after the examination and by the suffrages of men that divinity may be ascribed.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:37
verses.text: Thus, then, if God does not suit man, He cannot be God, since God is to be judged and justified by man.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:38
verses.text: It will no doubt seem just to my lord and master to send another governor to Jerusalem in the place of Pilate, who ought to be ignominiously driven from the powerful post in which you placed him; for he has done the will of the Jews:  he has crucified Christ unjustly, without your order.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:39
verses.text: That you may enjoy health is my desire".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:40
verses.text: Abgar, having written this letter, placed a copy of it, with copies of the other letters, in his archives.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:41
verses.text: He wrote also to the young Nerseh, king of Assyria, at Babylon:—  Abgar's letter to Nerseh.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:42
verses.text: "Abgar, king of the Armenians, to my son Nerseh, greeting:—  "I have received your letter and acknowledgments.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:43
verses.text: I have released Beroze from his chains, and have pardoned his offences:  if this pleases you, give him the government of Nineveh.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:44
verses.text: But as to what you write to me about sending you the physician who works miracles and preaches another God superior to fire and water, that you may see and hear him, I say to you:  he was not a physician according to the art of men; he was a disciple of the Son of God, Creator of fire and water:  he has been appointed and sent to the countries of Armenia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:45
verses.text: But one of his principal companions, named Simon, is sent into the countries of Persia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:46
verses.text: Seek for him, and you will hear him, you as well as your father Ardachès.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:47
verses.text: He will heal all your diseases and will show you the way of life".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:48
verses.text: Abgar wrote also to Ardachès, king of the Persians, the following letter:—  Abgar's letter to Ardachès.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:49
verses.text: "Abgar, king of the Armenians, to Ardachès my brother, king of the Persians, greeting:—  "I know that you have heard of Jesus Christ the Son of God, whom the Jews have crucified, Jesus who was raised from the dead, and has sent His disciples through all the world to instruct men.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:50
verses.text: One of His chief disciples, named Simon, is in your Majesty's territories.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:51
verses.text: Seek for him, and you will find him, and he will cure you of all your maladies, and will show you the way of life, and you will believe in his words, you, and your brothers, and all those who willingly obey you.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:52
verses.text: It is very pleasant to me to think that my relations in the flesh will be also my relations, my friends, in the spirit".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 8:53
verses.text: Abgar had not yet received answers to these letters when he died, having reigned thirty-eight years.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:1
verses.text: IX.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:2
verses.text: Martyrdom of our apostles.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:3
verses.text: After the death of Abgar, the kingdom of Armenia was divided between two:  Ananoun, Abgar's son, reigned at Edessa, and his sister's son, Sanadroug, in Armenia.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:4
verses.text: What took place in their time has been previously told by others:  the apostle's arrival in Armenia, the conversion of Sanadroug and his apostasy for fear of the Armenian satraps, and the martyrdom of the apostle and his companions in the canton of Chavarchan, now called Ardaz, and the stone opening to receive the body of the apostle, and the removal of this body by his disciples, his burial in the plain, and the martyrdom of the king's daughter, Santoukhd, near the road, and the apparition of the remains of the two saints, and their removal to the rocks—all circumstances related by others, as we have said, a long time before us:  we have not thought it important to repeat them here.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:5
verses.text: In the same way also what is related of the martyrdom at Edessa of Attaeus, a disciple of the apostle, a martyrdom ordered by Abgar's son, has been told by others before us.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:6
verses.text: The prince who reigned after the death of his father, did not inherit his father's virtues:  he opened the temples of the idols, and embraced the religion of the heathen.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:7
verses.text: He sent word to Attaeus:  "Make me a head-dress of cloth interwoven with gold, like those you formerly used to make for my father".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:8
verses.text: He received this answer from Attaeus:  "My hands shall not make a head-dress for an unworthy prince, who does not worship Christ the living God".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:9
verses.text: Immediately the king ordered one of his armed men to cut off Attaeus' feet.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:10
verses.text: The soldier went, and, seeing the holy man seated in the chair of the teacher, cut off his legs with his sword, and immediately the saint gave up the ghost.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:11
verses.text: We mention this cursorily, as a fact related by others a long while ago.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:12
verses.text: There came then into Armenia the Apostle Bartholomew, who suffered martyrdom among us in the town of Arepan.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:13
verses.text: As to Simon, who was sent unto Persia, I cannot relate with certainty what he did, nor where he suffered martyrdom.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:14
verses.text: It is said that one Simon, an apostle, was martyred at Veriospore.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 9:15
verses.text: Is this true, or why did the saint come to this place? I do not know; I have only mentioned this circumstance that you may know I spare no pains to tell you all that is necessary.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:1
verses.text: X.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:2
verses.text: Reign of Sanadroug; murder of Abgar's children; the princess Helena.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:3
verses.text: Sanadroug, being on the throne, raises troops with the help of the brave Pacradouni and Ardzrouni, who had exalted him, and goes to wage war upon the children of Abgar, to make him self master of the whole kingdom.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:4
verses.text: Whilst Sanadroug was occupied with these affairs, as if by an effect of divine providence vengeance was taken for the death of Attaeus; for a marble column which the son of Abgar was having erected at Edessa, on the summit of his palace, while he was underneath to direct the work, escaped from the hands of the workmen, fell upon him and crushed his feet.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:5
verses.text: Immediately there came a message from the inhabitants of the town, asking Sanadroug for a treaty by which he should engage not to disturb them in the exercise of the Christian religion, in consideration of which, they would give up the town and the king's treasures.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:6
verses.text: Sanadroug promised, but in the end violated his oath.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:7
verses.text: Sanadroug put all the children of the house of Abgar to the edge of the sword, with the exception of the daughters, whom he withdrew from the town to place them in the canton of Hachdiank.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:8
verses.text: As to the first of Abgar's wives, named Helena, he sent her to his town at Kharan, and left to her the sovereignty of the whole of Mesopotamia, in remembrance of the benefits he had received from Abgar by Helena's means.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:9
verses.text: Helena, pious like her husband Abgar, did not wish to live in the midst of idolaters; she went away to Jerusalem in the time of Claudius, during the famine which Agabus had predicted; with all her treasures she bought in Egypt an immense quantity of corn, which she distributed amongst the poor, a fact to which Josephus testifies.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 10:10
verses.text: Helena's tomb, a truly remarkable one, is still to be seen before the gate of Jerusalem.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:1
verses.text: XI.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:2
verses.text: Restoration of the town of Medzpine; name of Sanadroug; his death.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:3
verses.text: Of all Sanadroug's doings and actions, we judge none worthy of remembrance except the building of the town of Medzpine; for, this town having been shaken by an earthquake, Sanadroug pulled it down, rebuilt it more magnificently, and surrounded it with double walls and ramparts.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:4
verses.text: Sanadroug caused to be erected in the middle of the town his statue holding in his hand a single piece of money, which signifies:  "All my treasures have been used in building the town, and no more than this single piece of money is left to me".

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:5
verses.text: But why was this prince called Sanadroug?  We will tell you:  Because Abgar's sister, Otaea, while travelling in Armenia in the winter, was assailed by a whirlwind of snow in the Gortouk mountains; the tempest separated them all, so that none of them knew where his companion had been driven.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:6
verses.text: The prince's nurse, Sanod, sister of Piourad Pacradouni, wife of Khosran Ardzrouni, having taken the royal infant, for Sanadroug was still in the cradle, laid him upon her bosom, and remained with him under the snow three days and three nights.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:7
verses.text: Legend has taken possession of this circumstance:  it relates that an animal, a new species, wonderful, of great whiteness, sent by the gods, guarded the child.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:8
verses.text: But so far as we have been informed, this is the fact:  a white dog, which was amongst the men sent in search, found the child and his nurse; the prince was therefore called Sanadroug, a name taken from his nurse's name (and from the Armenian name, dourk, a gift), as if to signify the gift of Sanod.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:9
verses.text: Sanadroug, having ascended the throne in the twelfth year of Ardachès, king of the Persians, and having lived thirty years, died as he was hunting, from an arrow which pierced his bowels, as if in punishment of the torments which he had made his holy daughter suffer.

verses.name: Syriac: Moses of Chorene 11:10
verses.text: Gheroupna, son of the scribe Apchatar, collected all these facts, happening in the time of Abgar and Sanadroug, and placed them in the archives of Edessa.
